exam_title: CAAP PPL Airman Knowledge - Aircraft General Knowledge (AGK)

questions.question_text: According to the provided text, what type of fuel is commonly used in Cessna 152-172 aircraft?
Which type of fuel system relies solely on gravity to deliver fuel to the engine?
What is the primary purpose of the primer in a fuel system?
options: To filter the fuel before it enters the engine
To measure the fuel quantity in the tanks
To inject a small amount of fuel directly into the cylinders for easier starting
To switch between different fuel tanks
questions.correct_answer: To inject a small amount of fuel directly into the cylinders for easier starting

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of the fuel sump drain ports?
options: To add fuel to the tanks
To allow testing of fuel for contaminants like water or sediment
questions.correct_answer: To allow testing of fuel for contaminants like water or sediment

questions.question_text: Why is there always some unusable fuel in aircraft fuel tanks?
options: It serves as a reserve for emergencies
It is below the level of the fuel line pickup point
It is required for weight and balance
It is used to cool the fuel pumps
questions.correct_answer: It is below the level of the fuel line pickup point

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT listed as a primary function of the engine oil system?
options: Cooling the engine by reducing friction
Providing fuel pressure to the carburetor
questions.correct_answer: Providing fuel pressure to the carburetor

questions.question_text: What type of oil system is typically used in the aircraft discussed to reduce weight?
What type of oil is recommended for the first 50 hours of engine operation (break-in period)?
A rapid drop in oil pressure to zero most likely indicates:
options: A blockage in the oil system
A blown oil line or oil pump failure
The oil quantity is slightly low
questions.correct_answer: A blown oil line or oil pump failure

questions.question_text: What does an abnormally high oil temperature reading typically indicate?
options: The oil pump is not functional
There is a blockage in the oil system
The oil quantity is too high

questions.question_text: Which component is used to manually check the engine oil quantity?
What is a major consequence of operating an engine at higher than its designed temperature?
options: Loss of power and potential engine damage
questions.correct_answer: Loss of power and potential engine damage

questions.question_text: Which components on the engine cylinders help dissipate heat into the surrounding air?
What is the function of cowl flaps?
options: To increase aerodynamic drag during landing
To control the amount of cooling air flowing over the engine
To direct exhaust gases away from the cabin
questions.correct_answer: To control the amount of cooling air flowing over the engine

questions.question_text: How is cabin heating typically provided in many light aircraft?
options: Using an electric heater powered by the battery
Using residual heat from the avionics
Using fresh air heated by the exhaust system muffler
questions.correct_answer: Using fresh air heated by the exhaust system muffler

questions.question_text: What does the Exhaust Gas Temperature (EGT) gauge measure?
options: The temperature of the engine oil
The temperature of the gases at the exhaust manifold
The temperature of the cylinder heads
questions.correct_answer: The temperature of the gases at the exhaust manifold

questions.question_text: What are the typical DC voltages found in aircraft electrical systems mentioned in the text?
What is the primary function of the aircraft battery when the engine is not running?
options: To provide primary power for all systems
To provide power for starting the engine and emergency power
To regulate the voltage output of the alternator
questions.correct_answer: To provide power for starting the engine and emergency power

questions.question_text: Which component supplies electrical power to the system and recharges the battery once the engine is running?
What is a key advantage of an alternator over a generator, according to the text?
options: Alternators are lighter and require less maintenance
Alternators produce more constant electrical output across a wider range of engine speeds
Generators are more reliable at low RPM
questions.correct_answer: Alternators produce more constant electrical output across a wider range of engine speeds

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of circuit breakers or fuses in an aircraft electrical system?
options: To protect circuits and equipment from electrical overload
questions.correct_answer: To protect circuits and equipment from electrical overload

questions.question_text: What does the illumination of the beacon light typically indicate?
options: The aircraft is ready for takeoff
The landing gear is down and locked
The engine is about to start or is running
questions.correct_answer: The engine is about to start or is running

questions.question_text: What are the standard colors and positions for aircraft navigation lights?
options: Left Wing: Green, Right Wing: Red, Tail: White
Left Wing: Red, Right Wing: Green, Tail: White
Left Wing: White, Right Wing: White, Tail: Red
Left Wing: Red, Right Wing: Red, Tail: Green
questions.correct_answer: Left Wing: Red, Right Wing: Green, Tail: White

questions.question_text: What is the function of a Bus Bar in an aircraft electrical system?
options: To provide a common connection point for distributing voltage
questions.correct_answer: To provide a common connection point for distributing voltage

questions.question_text: What does an Ammeter typically measure in an aircraft electrical system?
options: The voltage output of the alternator
The total electrical load on the system
The electrical current flowing into or out of the battery
The resistance in the electrical circuits
questions.correct_answer: The electrical current flowing into or out of the battery

questions.question_text: What does a Loadmeter typically indicate?
options: The amount of charge remaining in the battery
The rate of current flow to the battery
The total percentage load being placed on the alternator/generator
The voltage level of the electrical system
questions.correct_answer: The total percentage load being placed on the alternator/generator

questions.question_text: What system powers some gyroscopic flight instruments in many light aircraft?
The pitot tube is used to measure which type of pressure?
Which flight instrument is connected ONLY to the pitot pressure source (directly)?
What pressure does the static port measure?
Which flight instrument operates using BOTH pitot and static pressure?
What does the Airspeed Indicator (ASI) actually measure?
options: The difference between total pressure and static pressure
questions.correct_answer: The difference between total pressure and static pressure

questions.question_text: What is Indicated Airspeed (IAS)?
options: Airspeed corrected for altitude and temperature
The uncorrected reading obtained directly from the Airspeed Indicator
The actual speed of the aircraft over the ground
questions.correct_answer: The uncorrected reading obtained directly from the Airspeed Indicator

questions.question_text: True Airspeed (TAS) is Calibrated Airspeed (CAS) corrected for:
What does the white arc on the Airspeed Indicator represent?
What is Vso?
options: Stalling speed in the landing configuration (lower limit of white arc)
Maximum speed with flaps extended (upper limit of white arc)
questions.correct_answer: Stalling speed in the landing configuration (lower limit of white arc)

questions.question_text: What does the green arc on the Airspeed Indicator represent?
What speed is indicated by the red radial line on the Airspeed Indicator (Vne)?
Which V-speed represents the best angle-of-climb speed?
Which V-speed represents the best rate-of-climb speed?
The Altimeter measures the height of an aircraft above:
What type of altitude is read directly from the altimeter when set to the local altimeter setting (QNH)?
What is Pressure Altitude?
options: Actual height above Mean Sea Level (MSL)
Altitude shown when the altimeter is set to 29.92 in Hg (ISA standard pressure)
questions.correct_answer: Altitude shown when the altimeter is set to 29.92 in Hg (ISA standard pressure)

questions.question_text: Density Altitude is Pressure Altitude corrected for:
Which altimeter setting would a pilot use to have the altimeter read the field elevation upon landing?
The Vertical Speed Indicator (VSI) operates using pressure from which source?
options: Both Pitot tube and Static port

questions.question_text: What is the 'Trend' indication on a VSI?
options: The stabilized rate of climb or descent after 6-9 seconds
The immediate indication of a change in vertical direction
questions.correct_answer: The immediate indication of a change in vertical direction

questions.question_text: If the pitot tube becomes blocked but the drain hole remains open, what will the Airspeed Indicator show?
options: Airspeed freezes at the value when blockage occurred

questions.question_text: If both the pitot tube opening and its drain hole become clogged, how will the Airspeed Indicator react?
options: It will freeze at the last correct indication
It will act like an altimeter (increase in climb, decrease in descent)
It will read lower than actual airspeed
questions.correct_answer: It will act like an altimeter (increase in climb, decrease in descent)

questions.question_text: If the static port becomes blocked, which instruments will provide inaccurate readings?
What gyroscopic principle allows a gyro to remain fixed in its plane of rotation?
Which gyroscopic instrument provides pitch and roll information?
Due to precession, the Heading Indicator must be periodically realigned with which instrument?
How often should the Heading Indicator typically be checked and realigned during straight-and-level flight?
What information does the Turn Coordinator provide?
What is the standard rate of turn indicated by the Turn Coordinator?
What is Magnetic Variation?
options: Error caused by the aircraft's magnetic fields
The tendency of the compass to dip towards the poles
The angular difference between True North and Magnetic North
The error caused by accelerating or decelerating
questions.correct_answer: The angular difference between True North and Magnetic North

questions.question_text: What causes Magnetic Deviation?
options: The difference between True North and Magnetic North
Disturbances from magnetic fields produced by metals and electrical accessories within the airplane
questions.correct_answer: Disturbances from magnetic fields produced by metals and electrical accessories within the airplane

questions.question_text: In the Northern Hemisphere, when accelerating on an East or West heading, the magnetic compass tends to indicate a turn towards:
In the Northern Hemisphere, when initiating a turn from a Northerly heading, the magnetic compass indication will initially:
According to PCAR Part 1, what defines an aircraft as 'Airworthy'?
options: It has passed its last inspection
It has a valid Certificate of Registration
It conforms to its approved design and is in a condition for safe operation
It has flown less than 100 hours since the last overhaul
questions.correct_answer: It conforms to its approved design and is in a condition for safe operation

questions.question_text: What is the typical validity period for a Certificate of Airworthiness in the Philippines before renewal is required?
Which document, signed by an authorized representative of an AMO, certifies that maintenance work has been completed satisfactorily?
Who holds the primary responsibility for maintaining an aircraft in an airworthy condition?
options: The Civil Aviation Authority of the Philippines (CAAP)
The owner or lessee of the aircraft
questions.correct_answer: The owner or lessee of the aircraft

questions.question_text: Which instrument is required for VFR flight at night, but not necessarily during the day, according to the provided list?
What is a Supplemental Type Certificate (STC)?
options: The original approval for an aircraft design
An approval for a major change in type design of an already approved product
A certificate required for experimental aircraft
questions.correct_answer: An approval for a major change in type design of an already approved product

questions.question_text: Which aircraft category permits limited acrobatics with bank angles between 60° and 90°?
An aircraft used for agricultural purposes like crop dusting would typically fall under which category?
What type of fuselage construction uses a substructure riveted to the skin to maintain shape and strength, common in modern light aircraft?
Which wing planform is described as ideal for subsonic speeds but difficult to manufacture?
Which flight control surfaces move in opposite directions to cause the airplane to roll?
What is the primary function of flaps?
options: To increase lift and drag, allowing for steeper approaches and slower landing speeds
To trim the aircraft for level flight
questions.correct_answer: To increase lift and drag, allowing for steeper approaches and slower landing speeds

questions.question_text: What part of the empennage controls the airplane's yaw (movement of the nose left and right)?
What part of the empennage controls the airplane's pitch (movement of the nose up and down)?
What is the purpose of an elevator trim tab?
options: To increase the structural integrity of the elevator
To help the pilot hold the elevator in a desired position, reducing control pressure
To act as a secondary elevator in case of primary control failure
To increase the effectiveness of the elevator at high speeds
questions.correct_answer: To help the pilot hold the elevator in a desired position, reducing control pressure

questions.question_text: What type of landing gear configuration has a single nose wheel and two main wheels?
What type of shock absorber, using air and oil, is commonly found on nose landing gear?
What is the primary function of the propeller?
options: To translate engine power into thrust
questions.correct_answer: To translate engine power into thrust

questions.question_text: What is a characteristic of a 'Climb Propeller'?
options: Less twist, designed for high cruise speeds
Variable pitch controlled by the pilot
More twist (bigger bite), optimized for climb performance
questions.correct_answer: More twist (bigger bite), optimized for climb performance

questions.question_text: What is the advantage of a Constant Speed Propeller?
options: It is simpler and lighter than fixed-pitch propellers
It allows the pilot to maintain a constant airspeed
It automatically adjusts pitch to maintain a selected RPM for better efficiency
questions.correct_answer: It automatically adjusts pitch to maintain a selected RPM for better efficiency

questions.question_text: What type of engine uses the back-and-forth movement of pistons to convert pressure into rotating motion?
Which cylinder arrangement is noted for having a good power-to-weight ratio and good cooling but potentially large frontal area?
Which cylinder arrangement is common in light general aviation aircraft due to good cooling, less vibration, and small frontal area?
Which engine component connects the piston to the crankshaft?
What are the four strokes of a typical reciprocating engine cycle?
What event occurs between the compression and power strokes?
What is detonation in an engine cylinder?
options: Normal, smooth burning of the fuel-air mixture
Ignition of the fuel-air mixture before the spark plug fires
Uncontrolled, explosive ignition of the fuel-air mixture
Incomplete combustion resulting in black smoke
questions.correct_answer: Uncontrolled, explosive ignition of the fuel-air mixture

questions.question_text: What is pre-ignition?
options: The spark plug firing at the correct time
Ignition of the fuel-air mixture before the spark plug fires, often caused by a hot spot
Explosive burning of the fuel-air mixture
The process of priming the engine before start
questions.correct_answer: Ignition of the fuel-air mixture before the spark plug fires, often caused by a hot spot

questions.question_text: What does the Tachometer indicate?
options: Engine crankshaft speed in RPM (Revolutions Per Minute)
questions.correct_answer: Engine crankshaft speed in RPM (Revolutions Per Minute)

questions.question_text: Under what conditions is carburetor icing most likely, according to the text?
options: Only when visible moisture is present

questions.question_text: What component generates the high voltage required for the spark plugs in the ignition system?
During a magneto check, what is the typical maximum allowable RPM drop for a single magneto?
During a magneto check, what is the typical maximum allowable difference in RPM drop between the left and right magnetos?
Which structural component forms the central body of the airplane, housing the crew and passengers?
What is the term for the tail assembly of an aircraft, typically consisting of the vertical and horizontal stabilizers?
Which basic flight maneuver is primarily controlled by the ailerons?
Which basic flight maneuver is primarily controlled by the rudder?
Which basic flight maneuver is primarily controlled by the elevator/stabilator?
According to PCAR Part 5, what is 'Continuing Airworthiness'?
options: The initial certification process for a new aircraft
The set of processes ensuring an aircraft remains compliant and safe throughout its operating life
A special flight permit for non-airworthy aircraft
The process of modifying an aircraft design
questions.correct_answer: The set of processes ensuring an aircraft remains compliant and safe throughout its operating life

questions.question_text: What is Ground Speed (GS)?
options: Indicated airspeed corrected for instrument error
Calibrated airspeed corrected for altitude and temperature
The aircraft's actual speed over the ground (TAS adjusted for wind)
questions.correct_answer: The aircraft's actual speed over the ground (TAS adjusted for wind)
